title: Opioid overdose recognition and management
text: Opioid overdose presents with miosis, respiratory depression, and depressed mental status. Immediate airway support and naloxone administration are critical. Arterial blood gas may reveal hypercapnic respiratory failure; monitoring for recurrent toxicity is required with long-acting opioids.

title: Organophosphate poisoning (cholinergic toxidrome)
text: Organophosphate exposure causes cholinergic toxidrome: miosis, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI upset, emesis, bronchorrhea, and bronchospasm. Serum cholinesterase activity is reduced. Management includes decontamination, atropine, and pralidoxime with airway support.

title: Acetaminophen toxicity evaluation
text: Acetaminophen overdose may present with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain. Transaminitis develops within 24–72 hours. The serum acetaminophen level plotted on the Rumack–Matthew nomogram guides N-acetylcysteine therapy timing.
